title: Food for Thought
body:
So Riot has mentioned that balancing has been made difficult in the past due to coordinated pro play vs. Soloq. 

It should be very clear to everyone that in league we play in two different universes. There are the pros who travel the world and compete for various silver cups. And there is us, average casual everyday "play a game after work" type people. Kennen to you is completely different than Kennen to the pros etc.

So I was thinking, and it might sound over ambitious or a little naive but why don't they just make two completely different clients or something?

Like one for us the casuals and one for the pros. Same game, same champs, same everything. One exception though. Each client has it's own balance team designated to it. The pro pool balancing team focuses on making changes to champions with high level coordinated play in mind; whilst the Casual pool balancing team perhaps focuses on changes that are more focused on the player at least slightly moreso then the team. 

Call me crazy, call it impossible, but you know what? I would like it, and i don't think i'm the only one who would. 

Anyone else think this would be a cool idea? Anyone care to expand?

replies.body:
It would probably be pretty frustrating to pro players to do this.

Imagine if the only way you could practice the game solo was on patch 5.16 (picking a random number) but when it came time to play your serious team games you played on 7.3.

It would only work if the game stayed relatively similar between the two with only a few minor number tweaks between live and pro play but keeping it like that would be a nightmare.

The easiest thing to get thrown off would be build paths and at that point does riot balance so that the new build path on the pro patch matches the build path on live? 

I'll try to give an random example of what I am talking about but it is hard to describe how this can go off the rails.

What if on live Sion becomes an mid lane ad burst champ but in the pro play patch he is still a tank and his playstyle as a result veers off in 2 different directions which suddenly makes vayne op on one version so her attack speed has to be nerfed and that makes frozen heart a better buy and so on.... meanwhile none of this stuff happens on the other version so all of these changes cascade in completely different directions.

Not saying any of this nonsense would happen but it is easy to see how one or two small changes can affect the game as a whole and make the two into completely different games very quickly.

You raise a good point, however to my knowledge the pros don't practice in soloq. Im positive they practice as 5 against other teams of a similar caliber. I Have even heard of pro teams having their own backup players playing custom 5v5s with the teams current roster for practicing. So I don't think this would pose a massive issue.

Oh absolutely, the sheer volume of changes made to cater towards one or the other is so frustrating. I'd love it if we had two separate clients. I think the major issue with that, however, is the amount of dedicated "balancers" that would be required. Otherwise, I'm in.

I would tend to agree with your statement. But upon further thought I must decline considering the fact that the balancing conundrum that riot faces today would be solved, i figure it would be easier for them to balance the game for both parties separately. Then again, I could be wrong but I think it would actually take a similar if not less amount of "blancers" to work their magic.
I see no downside to this.
Well there is, as much as I love the idea, riot would have to put extra work into individually making patches for each client

There is only one true obstacle to this idea, and that is Riot's stance on the issue, they want to keep the champions the same across casual and pro play so that ordinary people can look at pro play and see what can be done with the same tools that they have. They don't want pro play to become a different beast that ordinary people can't relate to.

Besides, what do you think will come of it if Riot doesn't consider balance for high level coordinated play? It will just lead to a lot of OP champions, its just that most can't access what makes them OP most of the time, but that doesn't mean that it won't cause problems.

True, I think this is where I disagree with Riots approach to the game. I don't see any good that can come out of giving the player base a false illusion of being like a pro besides revenue for them. And when the discussion comes down to money we will lose 10 times out of 10. Regarding new champ releases, I'm frankly tired of new champs and have been for a couple years. I feel like we have enough variety in this game, and considering how rocky the balancing is going, introducing new champs every couple months just metastasizes the problem even more. IMHO

The only false illusion lies in the coordination, if Riot can solve for that then there will be no difference other then skill. Not exactly a insurmountable task, if given the proper tools its mostly in the hands of the players. Alright so maybe it is insurmountable to get people to work together. XD

I don't know how you got on champ releases or what that has to do with anything. But, I find that new champions are a very good thing, the game gets stale without them, besides, the new champions are far more interesting then the old ones.

For most of us, realistically we can make it to challenger one day. If we work hard and learn lessons every game. But even in the current state of the game I can't say the same for becoming a professional. It's out of the realm of possibility even in my ambitious mind, comparable to winning the lottery. As far as coordination I have thought many times that a voice chat system would work wonders for that.  And the new release blurb, I don't really know where that came from, i'm pretty gassed, long work week. But yeah, I guess i'm just salty with most of Riots new champs and reworks as I find them to be poorly balanced a majority of the time. Which probably has something to do with the pros vs. casuals conundrum once again. I dunno.

I really doubt new champions or reworks being unbalanced has anything to do with pro play. Unless pro's have secret tournaments before the new champion releases where they get to use them and affect the stats on release.

If your looking to blame anyone, blame the PBE people and the balance teams, but what's the point of that really, not like these people are perfect. Properly balancing champions requires a lot of data and time and a lot of testing.

Feels more like I'm talking to an old man who can't keep up with the youngsters anymore. XD

>So Riot has mentioned that balancing has been made difficult in the past due to coordinated pro play vs. Soloq.

they did it to themselves by forcing the 'team game' meme on soloQ players
Im pretty sure that is Obvious information to the majority of the player base albeit irrelevant information to this post.
Even if it did exist, Miss Fortune support would've still haunted solo queue for the next 2 months after worlds

Perhaps, but I think players who copy what the pros do would only find themselves tanking their MMR eventually simply because of their lack of knowledge of the soloq meta. In which case folks like us wouldn't have to worry since they would be in a completely different division of their own. The infamous wood tier.

the problem with that is pros play standards too; balancing competitive and casual separately is a pipedream.

The only way you could do this is by having a "ranked" and "normals" client.

I don't quite understand what you are saying here, but i'm going to take a shot at it. If by standards you mean they play in soloq, then sure but I don't see why that would effect changes for soloq players. If a pro player is playing solo, without a coordinated ranked 5's team he should be entitled to the same balancing as we have should he not?

The whole idea is balancing the game on whether you are in game with a group of people on microphones playing at a high level with a high level of understanding of the game and mechanics vs. playing by yourself, with 4 random people you don't know and your most effective tool for communicating with them are 4 pings. 

Communication makes a colossal difference in the result of the game, especially nowadays, with the balance changes becoming more and more focused on teamwork and team strategies and compositions. 

Not sure if i misunderstood you, just wanted to make sure i clarify that.
